Systems of Equations in Matrix Form

children.label: Systems of Equations in Matrix Form

children.value: One of the uses of linear algebra in economics is to represent and then solve systems of equations. For instance, consider the system:

children.html: 3x1+4x2=53x_{1}+4x_{2}=53x1​+4x2​=5
7x1−2x2=27x_{1}-2x_{2}=27x1​−2x2​=2

children.value: This is equivalent to the matrix form

children.value: Interchanging any two rows or columns changes the sign of the determinant.
Multiplying a single row or column by a scalar multiplies the determinant by that scalar.
Addition or subtraction of a nonzero multiple of a row/column to another does not change the determinant.
The determinant of a triangular matrix is the product of the diagonal elements.
If any rows or columns equal zero, the determinant is zero.
If two rows or columns are linearly dependent, the determinant is zero.
